item.title: 4-Point Bending
item.description: For the 4-point load test, we only performed the real-life experiment. Similar to the cantilever experiment, we used an aluminum bar outfitted with a strain gage. Essentially the same analysis was performed as for the cantilever experiment, with the principal and shear strains being calculated from the strain gage data. Then with simple beam analysis the bending force and moment could be calculated, which were used to compute the bending stress at the top surface of the beam. This in turn could be used to compute Poisson’s ratio and the elastic modulus, resulting in an even more accurate estimate of 3.246 for Poisson’s and an identical elastic modulus to the cantilever experiment.

item.title: Cantilever Beam Analysis
item.description:
The second solids simulation I conducted was a beam-bending problem. First I worked out the problem analytically given the boundary conditions (bending and torsion) then ran a similar simulation in ANSYS. The simulation resulted in a slightly larger displacement and significantly lower twist angle, possibly due to the fact that the analytical solution did not consider the endcap used in the simulation geometry. Next, a modal analysis was performed in ANSYS revealing three mode frequencies characterized by strong z-axis bending, strong y-axis bending, and torsion respectively (the shapes for these last two modes shown in the last two images below). Given that the beam loaded under the provided boundary condition appears to be characterized by torsion and y-axis bending, it is likely that these two modes would be excited if the boundary conditions were suddenly removed and the system allowed to vibrate freely.

For the final set of experiments in the course, we learned to use strain gages by conducting a cantilever beam test to verify Poisson’s ratio for aluminum.

The cantilever beam test was quite straightforward so two variants were conducted: load controlled, where weights were incrementally added to the edge of the beam, and displacement controlled where a micrometer was used to deflect the beam. The strain gage data was converted in MATLAB using the strain transformation equations and plotted against the loads. These relationships were analyzed with Euler-Bernoulli beam theory, yielding an estimate for the elastic modulus of 68.7 GPa, very close to the tabulated value of 69 GPa for aluminum. All this data in turn could be used to compute Poisson’s ratio. The average value found between the trials was .306, fairly close to the tabulated value of 0.33.

item.title: Tensile Testing
item.description:
The first set of solids simulations in this course was a simple demonstration of plastic and elastic deformations of an aluminum ‘dogbone’ plate. In the first plot we can clearly see the internal stress increasing until the material fails and begins to deform plastically and stress ceases increasing. In the second plot, a plate is again loaded linearly but stopped just short of failure. Although the material is still irreversibly deformed, it relaxes linearly, or elastically, to a significantly lower displacement than it was loaded to. For one extra variable, the simulations were performed on geometries both with and without a hole punched through the center. Unsurprisingly, the perforated plates failed at significantly lower loads due to the extreme stress that develops around the hole.

In the second term, this same test was performed on actual aluminum plates with a tensile testing apparatus and a high-speed camera for DIC (digital image correlation). Aside from generating the pretty strain plots below, I was also able to use Hooke’s law for stress-strain relation to derive an experimental estimate for the stress intensity factor, K. The K value of 2.336 was only off by under 1.4% from the theoretical value.

item.title: Engine Nacelle Analysis
item.description:
The second simulation for this course consisted of testing various mesh settings and CFD techniques for a straight pipe and an engine nacelle, allowing us to get more practice with ANSYS Fluent and learning to model axisymmetric flows.

The results were not as interesting as for the airfoil simulations. For the straight pipe I found that the steady-state inviscid model (Spalart-Allmaras) could not converge, while the transient inviscid and steady-state viscous models both converged and showed similar flow features as well as satisfying the continuity equation. Since this geometry was quite simple mesh type did not matter much.

For the engine nacelle, mesh density greatly affected the results. Once the mesh was properly refined, the Spalart-Allmaras model was found to be the best solution as it returned a much higher bypass ratio (due to the multiple boundary layers in close proximity, slowing flow through the center of the engine)

We again returned to the water tunnel to examine a 3-D printed engine nacelle similar to the one we modeled. Since this experiment involved running the water pump at different frequencies, we again collected data upstream of the test sample to experimentally determine the freestream velocity for each pump setting.

item.title: Airfoil Analysis
item.description:
For the simulations assignment, we tested different mesh geometries and simulation settings to see which would most accurately predict the lift/drag coefficients. I found that the inviscid simulation yielded the most accurate lift coefficient, while the steady-state model did not even converge to a solution. The transient model captured the turbulent effects that would probably be observed in the real world, but yielded very poor estimates for the lift and drag coefficients. I later learned that I had one of the most accurate estimates in the class because I had used an ‘inflation layer’ in my mesh, which added increased definition directly outside the airfoil to allow for superior modeling of the boundary layer.

In the second term, we conducted actual water tunnel experiments on the same airfoil. Using the PIV (particle-image-velocimetry) data gathered upstream, I was able to estimate a freestream velocity. Data was also gathered from the trailing edge of the airfoil, allowing me to derive drag coefficients from Bernoulli’s and the Navier-Stokes equation. Whether calculated using the experimentally-determined freestream velocity or that provided by the water pump manufacturer, there is clearly a sharp increase in drag after the airfoil is tilted beyond about 10 degrees. I also made vorticity plot for the flows, and found that there was severe vortex shedding at the higher angles. By performing an FFT, I found the shedding frequency to be about 6.3 Hz, very close to the theoretical estimate.

item.title: Amphibious Tank Robot Design
item.description:
For my senior capstone design project, I was put into a team of 5 to design and fabricate three robots for competition against our peers. The competition area was a pond divided into three sections separated by ramps, meaning we needed amphibious vehicles. The competition objectives involved picking up various colored balls from the arena and moving transporting them to specific zones to score points.

Our strategy was to design two large, expensive fully amphibious tank-boats that would be capable of storing as many balls as we could find. The third robot was made using the leftover budget and was a simple, lightweight fanboat with tiny wheels on the bottom for traversing ramps. Our large vehicles consisted of a Teflon-like HDPE thermoformed hull. It was fitted to CNC’ed aluminum plates with bolts and silicone gaskets. A shovel-like mechanism on the front and a moveable wall on the back were mounted to shafts and connected to linear actuators to allow them to collect and eject balls. The land locomotion system consisted of tank-like treads powered by a brushless motor and gear drive. The water propulsion used custom 3-D printed waterjets and impellers with brushless motors. The cheaper third robot was constructed almost entirely of lasercut ABS. The control systems all used Arduinos with hobbyist ESCs.

item.title: Novel Carbon-Fiber Robot Design
item.description: Throughout my junior year I worked as the main mechanical designer on a robotics project at Caltech’s Center for Autonomous Systems Technology. The postdoc leading the project had already designed some of the core components on his own but I added much of the detail to the joints and chassis, integrated the off-the-shelf components, and designed much of the electronics mounting and other components in the ‘head’ of the robot. I also designed a housing/coupler for a BLDC motor, encoder, and planetary gearbox that was intended to be a potential replacement for the harmonic drive motors if the manufacturer could not fill the order in time, and a wheeled testbed for safely testing the robot. Unfortunately I left to work at Lockheed Martin for the summer before the electronics and software were fully built.

item.title: A* Maze Solver
item.description:
As my final project of the cross-listed mechanical engineering/computer science class, ME133: Autonomy, I implemented the A* graph-search algorithm in Python. It is an extension of Djisktra’s algorithm that uses a guiding heuristic function to ideally attain the result faster than Djisktra’s. The core logic of my code is in one of the pictures below. While there are libraries out there for implementing graphs in Python, I wanted to only use built-in data structures. I ended up using a dictionary that mapped the node coordinates to an array storing the distance from start node, heuristic value, total value, and the parent node coordinates. Once I worked out the data structures and the helper functions (calculate heuristic, find list of all valid neighbor nodes) it was simple to turn the A* pseudocode into Python code. I also implemented the ability to read in maps from CSV files and visualize the solutions using matplotlib.

import matplotlib as mpl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib import colors
import numpy as np
import csv
import copy

# User Defined Variables
# Note: Program assumes start and goal are within bounds of the map and that the map is
# rectangular (ie each sublist in the list has the same length)
# Map format should be csv with 1s as obstacles, 0s as free space
#start, goal, grid = (2,5), (9,5), list(csv.reader(open('C:\\Users\\Kanan\\Desktop\\Final Project\\map1.csv')))
start, goal, grid = (1,1), (1,98), list(csv.reader(open('F:\\Autonomy\\map3_zeroes.csv')))
grid = [[int(string) for string in inner] for inner in grid]

# Function for returning list of neighbor indices while ignoring non-existent ones
X = len(grid)-1
Y = len(grid[0])-1
neighbors = lambda x, y : [(x2, y2) for x2 in range(x-1, x+2)
                                   for y2 in range(y-1, y+2)
                                   if (-1 < x <= X and
                                       -1 < y <= Y and
                                       (x != x2 or y != y2) and
                                       (0 <= x2 <= X) and
                                       (0 <= y2 <= Y))]

# Straight-line distance, multiplied by 10 and rounded to the nearest integer for simplicity
def distance(coord1, coord2):
    return round(((coord1[0] - coord2[0])**2 + (coord1[1] - coord2[1])**2)**(1/2)*10)
# Apply distance formula to goal and given coordinate
def heuristic(coord):
    return distance(coord,goal)

# Initiate open list (with start coordinate already inside) and closed list            
opened = [start]
closed = []
# Using a dictionary as the data structure for storing node information
# Format - (i,j):[g, h, f, (k,l)] where i,j are node coordinates, g, h, f are the function values, and k,l are the parent coordinates
nodes = {start:[0,heuristic(start),0+heuristic(start),start]}

# Loop until open list is empty
while len(opened) > 0:
    minf = float("inf")
    # Find open node with mininum value and set to current
    for n in opened:
        if nodes[n][2] < minf:
            minf = nodes[n][2]
            current = n
    # Switch current node to closed list
    opened.remove(current)
    closed.append(current)
    # If current is goal then solution was found
    if current == goal:
        break
    # Investigate every open or unexplored, and traversable neighbor
    for n in neighbors(current[0],current[1]):
        g = nodes[current][0] + distance(current,n)
        if (n in closed) or (grid[n[0]][n[1]] == 1):
            pass
        # If neighbor is unexplored or has a suboptimal g-cost set current as parent, and update g and f
        elif (n not in opened) or (g < nodes[n][0]):
            nodes[n] = [g, heuristic(n),g+heuristic(n),current]
            # Add the previously unexplored neighbor to open list
            if (n not in opened):
                opened.append(n)

# If map was unsolved skip the path retrieva; and visualization parts of the script
if current != goal:
    print("Failure, map is unsolvable")
    quit()

# Retrieve the path by checking parent nodes, working backward from the goal
path = [goal]
i = 0                
while True:
    parent = nodes[path[i]][3]
    path.append(parent)
    i=i+1
    if parent == start:
        break
path.reverse()

# Visualization part of the program:
# Copy array for future modification
cgrid = np.array(grid)
# Fill array with 2, 3, 4 for opened, closed, or nodes lying on the path respectively
# Otherwise leave 0 or 1 which still represent free (unexplored) and occupied spaces respectively
for i in range(len(grid)):
    for j in range(len(grid[i])):
        if (i,j) in path:
            cgrid[i][j] = 2
#        elif (i,j) in opened:
#            cgrid[i][j] = 3
#        elif (i,j) in closed:
#            cgrid[i][j] = 2
# Map colors to the different values, effectively creating the following mapping
# Free (unexplored), Occupied, Opened, Closed, Path: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
cmap = colors.ListedColormap(['white','black','green'])
plt.imshow(cgrid,interpolation='nearest',cmap=cmap)

item.title: PID Ball Balancer
item.description: For the second project in my junior year design class, my team decided to design a ball-balancing mechanism in order to gain some experience with controls. The mechanical design was fairly simple. We mounted a plate onto a u-joint to allow it to pivot along the pitch and roll axes and connected arms to two perpendicular sides of the plate. We originally intended to use a resistive touch screen, but could not find one for a reasonable price. Luckily, I found the PixyCam, which allowed us to track the ball’s position visually using simple Arduino-compatible functions. After setting up the camera it was just a matter of implementing the Arduino PID algorithm library to controlling the servos and tweaking the PID constant values for better performance. This project had fewer manufacturing restrictions so while some parts were still purchased or manufactured on a manual mill or lathe, others were cut with a waterjet or laser.

item.title: Tensioned Belt-Drive Gearbox
item.description: For my first serious mechanical design project my group of 3 students was tasked with developing a gearbox to transmit torque from a small electric motor to a bicycle wheel. We were provided dimensions for the spacing and height of the couplings, the mounting geometry on the test platform, a recommended gear ratio, and a budget, but were otherwise left to our own devices. While most groups went with a simple spur gear design we decided to go with a dual-inline pulley design with an added tensioner/idler pulley. The bearings, belts, pulleys, springs, and fasteners were purchased but the rest of the components were machined by hand (with the exception of the decorative Pokemon plate, which was laser-etched).

item.title: Thruster Mount and Land Support Design for Robotics Team
item.description: I was active on the Caltech Robotics Team for a little over half of my junior year. My task was to design the thruster mounts for our small autonomous submarine. The thrusters were prototypes from the manufacturer VideoRay so I had to design the mounts to conform to their provided CAD. Initially the ‘foot’ of the vertical thruster mount was supposed to be on the inside, but the instrument teams requested it to be moved outside. Because of this, the assembly had to be reinforced with an extra piece attaching it to the submarine. Pocketing was also added to the ‘foot’ due to weight considerations.

item.title: Thales Project Arduino Competition
item.description: I’ll let our video report do the talking.

item.title: Waste Heat-Powered Environmental Sensor
item.description: For my first internship as a mechanical engineer I ended up with more of an electrical project, though working for a mechanical engineering and applied physics laboratory at Caltech. The goal was to design a system that draws and stores power into a supercapacitor from a thermoelectric generator (TEG) to power a microprocessor which takes and transmits temperature measurements. A previous prototype already existed, but it could only provide an adequate voltage to the microprocessor when the TEG was exposed to a huge temperature gradient, and would only sustain power for around 12 seconds when the heat source was removed. I improved this significantly by switching to a microprocessor that featured a deep sleep mode for reducing power consumption as well as more efficient temperature sensor and transceiver. Additionally, I used a larger heatsink and a superior voltage booster connected to the supercapacitor so that far less heat needed to be applied to turn on the processor. Lastly, I used a load switch to ensure the stored energy in the supercapacitor would not be wasted on the microprocessor until the voltage is high enough to properly power the device.

item.title: Semiconductor Fabrication and Materials Characterization
item.description: Although I switched to mechanical engineering three quarters of the way through my sophomore year, I was still interested in the materials side of applied physics so I decided to take a nanofabrication laboratory class for one of my advanced electives. Assignments included applying semiconductor processing techniques like etching and metal deposition to fabricating an LED from scratch, etching microscopic superhero symbols into silicon using an electron microscope, and fabricating simple microfluidic devices by creating molds out of silicon with custom-designed photoresist masks.

item.title: Four-State ‘Clap-On/Clap-Off’ Circuit
item.description:
Before I switched majors to mechanical engineering, I took a circuits class as part of the applied physics curriculum. It was largely about the applications of op-amps, along with some other useful active circuit elements like transistors and flip-flops. For the final project I designed a ‘clapper’ circuit which would cycle between four states (00,10,01,11) to light up two LEDs in the four different configurations possible. The basic design was a condenser mic, a bandpass filter to prevent sounds like footsteps and speaking from triggering the device, a preamplifier, a hysteretic comparator or Schmitt trigger to convert the mic signal from analog to digital. The Schmitt trigger in turn outputs to a vibrator circuit, which includes a 555 timer, to convert the trigger event (a clap) to a fixed width pulse of the appropriate amplitude. Lastly, this feeds into two cascaded flip flops which each output to one of the two LEDs.

Although the block diagram is lost to time, I still have a nice demonstration video.

item.title: Faraday Rotation Spectroscopy
item.description:
For my first college internship I returned to work at the University of Maryland, this time for the physics department’s Joint Quantum Institute. The goal of my project was to find a method for non-invasively measuring the magnetic field at the site of a sample of rubidium gas used for Bose-Einstein condensate experiments. The plan was to take advantage of the Faraday rotation effect. When light passes through a magnetic field in a medium, the plane of polarization of the light shifts in direct proportion to the magnetic field. By using a polarizing beam splitter and comparing the output of each side using photodiodes, the strength of the magnetic field can easily be calculated. In implementing this method I had to build a set of triaxial Helmholtz coils to be able to generate an arbitrary magnetic field around the sample, learn to use an oscilloscope, signal generator, magnetometer, Arduino, and many different types of optical components.

A second effort, which was not fully realized, was to generate a second, rapidly oscillating magnetic field perpendicular to the laser beam to induce Larmor precession, a periodic rotation of particles’ magnetic moments, which would yield a time-varying Faraday rotation effect that would allow for more accurate measurement of the constant magnetic field. In retrospect, this may not have been successful due to an impedance mismatch between the signal generator that caused the secondary magnetic field to be far too weak to produce the desired effect.

item.title: ANSYS Heatsink Simulations
item.description: My first experience with analysis was a high school internship at the University of Maryland. My project was a simple demonstration of the use of fins on heatsinks. I simulated a small flat heat generator on a larger block with air flowing past the bottom surface to symbolize a processor on a circuit board with a fan for airflow. I used ANSYS APDL to write a few scripts that would automatically lay out fins of the desired shape and size on the bottom of the heatsink. Unsurprisingly, the fin configuration with the most surface area resulted in the lowest temperatures in the device due to the greater effect of convection.

item.title: About Me
item.description:
Although I have a bachelor’s in mechanical engineering from Caltech, I am currently employed as an electrical test engineer at Lockheed Martin, and am set to begin a part-time master’s in computer science at Georgia Tech in the fall of 2020. Over the years, my interests have oscillated between robotics, aerospace, and advanced manufacturing.

Download my up-to-date resume

Employment

    Systems Integration and Test Engineer - September 2019 to Present

  • iRobot Corporation

  • Jim Hall Design and Prototyping Laboratory
    Teaching Assistant/Shop Supervisor - October 2018 to March 2019

  • Lockheed Martin Missiles & Fire Control: Microelectronics Center

  • Aerospace Robotics and Control Laboratory

item.title: Contact
item.description: In the interest of avoiding web-crawlers and spambots, please reach out to me via LinkedIn.

item.title: Non-Technical Work
item.description:
Over the years I’ve probably had as many blue-collar jobs and side hustles as technical jobs and internships. They’ve been great experiences, they allow me to meet new people, stay active, visit new places, and give my brain a much-needed break. The extra spending cash isn’t a bad perk either.

  • Special Event Security Guard (Winter X-Games), Securitas USA - January 2020

  • Teaching Assistant (Cooking Basics), Caltech - January 2019 to June 2019

  • Library Assistant, Caltech - May 2017 to June 2019

  • Information Systems & Services Representative, Caltech - February 2017 to September 2017

  • Dean’s Tutor, Caltech - September 2016 to June 2019

  • Mover, Self-Employed - May 2013 to September 2015

  • Sign-Spinner, Self-Employed - June 2012 to August 2012

item.title: Projects & Courses
item.description:
Georgia Tech

TBA

MOOCs

[Software] Algorithms Parts I & II - Princeton University via Coursera

One of the best courses I’ve ever taken - covers all the basics of algorithms and data structures: time complexity, sorts, graph theory, symbol tables, reduction, P = NP?, etc.

Caltech

[Mechanical] 4-Point Bending

Our final experiment, a 4-point load test on an aluminum bar. Results were used to confirm elastic modulus and Poisson’s ratio of aluminum.

[Mechanical] Cantilever Beam Analysis

For the final set of simulations, we analyzed a cantilever I-beam in simulation and a simple alumnimum bar in the lab.

[Mechanical] Tensile Testing

Moving onto solids, we examined plastic and elastic deformation by simulating a tensile test on a ‘dogbone’ geometry, and later again compared our simulation to real-life experiment.

[Mechanical] Engine Nacelle Analysis

Following up on the previous project, we conducted similar simulations and experiments except with an engine nacelle.

[Mechanical] Airfoil Analysis

I got to use ANSYS again for the first time since high school, to analyze a NACA airfoil. In the second half of this class we verified the simulation results by conducting a water tunnel experiment with the 3D printed airfoil.

[Mechanical] Amphibious Tank Robot Design

For my senior capstone design project I was teamed up with four other students to build three amphibious robots to compete in a game against our classmates. Although we didn’t win we definitely had one of the most ambitious designs.

[Mechanical] Novel Carbon-Fiber Robot Design

During my junior I was lucky enough to land a laboratory position as the lead mechanical designer for a novel walking/flying robot primarily fabricated with carbon fiber and 3D-printed parts.

[Mechanical] PID Ball Balancer

For my second major design project, I tried to get some more experience with electronics and coding by programming an Arduino with a PID algorithm to balance a rubber ball on a plate.

[Software] A* Maze Solver

The first graph algorithm I ever coded. Looking back, I did a terrible job but my code is in there in case anyone is interested.

[Mechanical] Tensioned Belt-Drive Gearbox

My first real design project, we made a gear box for gearing down a tiny high-speed motor to power a large bicycle wheel.

[Mechanical] Thruster Mount and Land Support Design for Robotics Team

I briefly volunteered on the robotics team doing mechanical design where I was able to put together these thruster mounts that ultimately were fabricated and included in the final assembly.

[Electronics] Thales Project Arduino Competition

My team and I devised a ‘smart bike alarm’ for participation in a Thales-sponsored competition. We ended up winning first place at our university.

[Electronics] Waste Heat-Powered Environmental Sensor

As a physics major, it was hard to lock down an industry internship in aerospace like I had hoped, but luckily I was able to find this Boeing-funded electronics project.

[Materials] Semiconductor Fabrication and Materials Characterization

Probably the coolest class I’ve taken, I learned to use SEM and AFM, and constructed multiple devices from bare materials including a red LED and a set of microfluidic channels.

[Electronics] Four-State ‘Clap-On/Clap-Off’ Circuit

Clap-on! Clap-off! The clapper!

University of Maryland

[Physics] Faraday Rotation Spectroscopy

First paid internship, back during my physics major days. Learned some useful lab and report-writing skills.

[Mechanical] ANSYS Heatsink Simulations

My first ever internship, doing thermal simulations in ANSYS.
